page.title: 5.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This lesson explores the meaning of rational exponents. Students begin reviewing how to simplify numbers using radicals with given roots. They start with square roots and perfect squares and move to make conclusions about cubed roots.

In the following activities, students work to write radicals as terms with rational exponents and vice versa. They then work to apply the properties for exponents to terms that include rational exponents.

In the cool-down, students also revisit negative exponents when exploring how properties work with rational exponents.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Simplify radical expressions with even and odd indexes.
  • Rewrite radicals as terms with rational exponents and vice versa.
  • Use properties for exponents with rational exponents.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Simplify radical expressions with even and odd indexes.
  • Rewrite expressions with rational exponents as roots.
  • Use properties for exponents with rational exponents.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A11(B) simplify numeric and algebraic expressions using the laws of exponents, including integral and rational exponents.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 5.2.1: Perfect Squares Revisited
  • 5.2.2: The nth Root
    • 5.2.2: Self Check 
    • 5.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 5.2.3: Radicals and Rational Exponents 
    • 5.2.3: Self Check 
    • 5.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 5.2.4: Properties of Exponents with Rationals 

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 5.2.5: Practice.

Required Materials

None

Required Preparation

None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:


Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • exponent
  • perfect square
  • square root
  • odd
  • even
  • radical
  • root
  • index
  • radicand

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their grit.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • All In
  • Success Story

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Grit from Character Lab.

page.title: 5.2.1: Perfect Squares Revisited
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm up reviews perfect squares and square roots and begins to elicit the idea of higher powers and the nth root.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2.

Student Activity

  1. What is the value of \(4 \times 4\)?

    Answer: 16
  1. What is the value of \(4^2\)?

    Answer: 16
  1. Using what you know about roots, what is the value of \(\sqrt{16}\)?

    Answer: 4
  1. Talk to a partner. How can you prove \(\sqrt[2]{4^2}\;=\;4\)?

    Answer: Since \(4^2\;=\;4\;\cdot\;4\;=\;16\) and \(\sqrt{16}\;=\;4\), \(\sqrt[2]{4^2}\;=\;4\).

    Notice that the root and exponents are the same and simplify to leave the integer only.

  1. Talk to a partner. What do you think the answer to \(\sqrt[5]{4^5}\) would be?

    Answer: \(\sqrt[5]{4^5}\;=\;4\)

Activity Synthesis

If time allows, continue to give more examples where the exponent and index of the root are the same. Ask students to come up with a rule or pattern.

page.title: 5.2.2: The nth Root
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to explore the parts of a radical as well as radicals with indexes above 2. Students may need a review of what an exponent does to a value, especially with negative numbers involved.

Launch

Arrange students into groups of 2.


Student Activity

Work with a partner to discuss and answer the following questions.

  1. Complete the table when \(n=-2\) on your paper and check your answer.

\(n\)

\(n^2\)

\(n^3\)

\(n^4\)

\(n^5\)

–2

        

Answer:

\(n\)

\(n^2\)

\(n^3\)

\(n^4\)

\(n^5\)

–2

 4 –8 16 –32

  1. What do you notice about the answers when the powers are even?

    Answer: They are positive.
  1. What do you notice about the answers when the powers are odd?

    Answer: They are negative.

The \(\sqrt a\), or square root of \(a\), is the same as \(\sqrt[2]a\). What about when we want to take roots that are higher than the square root? These are called radicals.

The nth root, or radical, is written \(\sqrt[n]a\). If \(b^n=a\), then \(b\) is an nth root of \(a\). The \(n\) is called the index of the radical. Just like \(\sqrt[2]n\) is called the square root, \(\sqrt[3]n\) is the cubed root, \(\sqrt[4]n\) is the fourth root, and so on. The number inside the radical is called the radicand.

  1. Using what you did with the powers in number 1, complete the table to find the roots of each.

\(4^3\;=\;64\)

 \(\sqrt[3]{64}\;=\;4\)

\(3^4\;=\;81\)

  
 

\(\sqrt[5]{-32}\;=\;-2\)

Answer:

\(4^3\;=\;64\)

 \(\sqrt[3]{64}\;=\;4\)

\(3^4\;=\;81\)

 \(\sqrt[5]{-32}\;=\;-2\)
\({(-2)}^5\;=\;-32\)

\(\sqrt[5]{-32}\;=\;-2\)

Could we have an even root of a negative number? We know that the square root of a negative number is not a real number. The same is true for any even root. Even roots of negative numbers are not real numbers. Odd roots of negative numbers are real numbers.

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may have trouble with multiplication of the negative signs and the rules associated with it. If needed, add another column to the table for students in their notebook to allow them to expand each term to find the answer, and then take the root.

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share how they arrived at their answers.

5.2.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION:

Simplify \(\sqrt[3]{-27}\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

3

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Think about what number is used as a factor 3 times to get –27. Watch the signs of the factor. The answer is –3.

9

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Think about what number is used as a factor 3 times to get –27. The answer is –3.

–3

That’s correct! Check yourself: \((-3)\;\times\;(-3)\;\times\;(-3)=-27\), so \(\sqrt[3]{-27}\;=\;-3\).

–9

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would be the result of dividing –27 by 3. Think about what number is used as a factor 3 times to get –27. The answer is –3.

5.2.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Simplifying Radicals

When simplifying radicals, think about which number will be used as a factor the number of times indicated by the index to get the number under the radical.

In the example above,

\(2\;\times\;2\;\times\;2=\;8\), so \(\sqrt[3]8\;=\;2\).

Remember, when the index is odd, the root is allowed to be negative. When the index is even, the root cannot be negative.

Try It: Simplifying Radicals

Simplify.

\(\sqrt[5]{-32}\;\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to simplify a radical:


Step 1
Identify the index.
5

Step 2
Identify the radicand (inside the radical).
–32

Step 3
What number can be used as a factor 5 times to get –32?
\((-2)\;\times\;(-2)\;\times\;(-2)\;\times\;(-2)\;\times\;(-2)=-32\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(\sqrt[5]{-32}\;=\;-2\)

page.title: 5.2.3: Radicals and Rational Exponents
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity allows students to write radicals as terms with rational exponents and vice versa.

Launch

Arrange students into groups of 2.


Student Activity

If \(\sqrt[n]{a^m}\) is a real number and \(n\;\geq\;2\), then \(\sqrt[n]{a^m}\;=\;a^\frac mn\).

So radicals can be rewritten as rational exponents.

  1. With a partner, write each radical as a term with rational exponents on your own paper. Then, turn and talk to your partner. Check your answers when you are ready.
    1. \(\sqrt[8]x\)

      Answer: \(x^\frac18\)

    2. \(\sqrt[3]{x^2}\)

      Answer: \(x^\frac23\)

    3. \(\sqrt[11]{x^5}\)

      Answer: \(x^\frac5{11}\)

  2. Now, with a partner, rewrite each term as an equivalent radical. Check your answer to each.
    1. \(x^\frac12\)

      Answer: \(\sqrt[2]x\;\) or \(\;\sqrt x\)

    2. \(x^\frac17\)

      Answer: \(\sqrt[7]x\;\)

    3. \(x^\frac45\)

      Answer: \(\sqrt[5]{x^4}\;\)

Video: Learning About Rational Exponents

Watch the following video to learn more about rational exponents.



Anticipated Misconceptions

When writing radicals as terms with rational exponents, it is important that the rational exponent has the original power on the top of the fraction and the index/root on the bottom.

A graphic organizer can help students as a reference for this.

Activity Synthesis

Invite pairs to share their answers. Allow students to make their own examples and then trade with other partner groups if time allows.

  • First, have each pair write an example as a radical and switch with another pair. Then each pair writes the term with the rational exponent that matches their radical.
  • Have each pair write a term with a rational exponent and then switch with another pair. Each pair writes the term as a radical.

5.2.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION:

Rewrite \(\sqrt[10]{x^7}\) as a term with a rational exponent.

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x^\frac{10}7\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 7 is the exponent, and the 10 is the index. The answer is \(x^\frac{7}{10}\).

\(x^\frac{7}{10}\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: The exponent gets written over the root.

\(10x^7\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 10 is the root, not a coefficient. The answer is \(x^\frac{7}{10}\).

\(\frac7{10}x\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The fraction should be the exponent. The answer is \(x^\frac{7}{10}\).

5.2.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Rewriting Radicals

When writing radicals as a term with a rational exponent, the exponent becomes the numerator of the fraction in the exponent, the root or index.

In the example above, the 2 is the exponent and becomes the top of the fraction. The 5 is the index and becomes the bottom of the fraction.

Try It: Rewriting Radicals

Write \(\sqrt[6]{x^5}\) as a term with a rational exponent.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to rewrite the radical expression:


Step 1
Identify the index.
6

Step 2
Identify the exponent (inside the radical).
5

Step 3
Write the power over the root.
\(x^\frac56\)

page.title: 5.2.4: Properties of Exponents with Rationals
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

The activities you learned in a prior lesson taught you the properties of exponents. These same properties work with rational exponents.

Simplify each, and then check your answers:

  1. \({(x^2)}^\frac13\)
    Answer: \(x^\frac23\)
  1. \(x^\frac23\;\cdot\;x^\frac23\)
    Answer: \(x^\frac43\)
  1. \({(x^{-3})}^\frac25\)
    Answer: \(x^{-\frac65}\;=\;\frac1{x^{\displaystyle^\frac65}}\)
  1. \({(x^\frac13)}^{-1}\)
    Answer: \(x^{-\frac13}\;=\;\frac1{x^{\displaystyle^\frac13}}\)

page.title: 5.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

  1. Simplify \(\sqrt[4]{81}\). Enter integers only.

ANSWER: 3

  1. Simplify \(\sqrt[5]{-32}\). Enter integers only.

ANSWER: –2

3. Which of the following is equivalent to \(\sqrt[4]{x^3}\)?

  1. \(x^\frac34\)
  2. \(x^\frac43\)
  3. \(4x^3\)
  4. \(\frac34x\)

ANSWER: a. \(x^\frac34\)

4. Which of the following is equivalent to \(\sqrt[9]{2^4}\)?

  1. \(2^\frac94\)
  2. \(\frac49(2)\)
  3. \(\frac{2^4}9\)
  4. \(2^\frac49\)

ANSWER: d. \(2^\frac49\)

5. Simplify \(k^3\;\cdot\;k^\frac13\).

  1. \(k\)
  2. \(\frac13k^3\)
  3. \(3k^\frac13\)
  4. \(k^\frac{10}3\)

ANSWER: d. \(k^\frac{10}3\)

6. Simplify \({(m^\frac34)}^{-2}\).

  1. \(m^\frac68\)
  2. \(\frac1{m^\frac32}\)
  3. \(m^\frac32\)
  4. \(-2m^\frac34\)

ANSWER: b. \(\frac1{m^\frac32}\)

7. True or false:

\(\sqrt[4]{-16}\;=\;-2\)

ANSWER: False

8. True or false:

\(\sqrt[3]{-64}\;=\;-4\)

ANSWER: True

9. Which of the following expressions are equivalent to perfect squares? Select all that apply.

  1. 25
  2. \(\sqrt{16}\)
  3. \(3+3\)
  4. \(\sqrt[5]{9^5}\)
  5. \(3\;\cdot\;2\)

ANSWER: a. 25, b. \(\sqrt{16}\), d. \(\sqrt[5]{9^5}\)

10. Which of the following is equivalent to \({(x^\frac15)}^4\)?

  1. \(x^4\)
  2. \(x^\frac45\)
  3. \(x^\frac4{20}\)
  4. \(x^{20}\)

ANSWER: b. \(x^\frac45\)

page.title: 5.2.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
In this lesson, students are introduced to the concept of roots above 2. They are also introduced to the concept that radicals can be written as terms with rational exponents.

Students may struggle with the properties for exponents when multiple properties are needed, for example, when negative exponents require an extra step.
